case_name: Not explicitly stated (Writ Petitions Nos. 34 of 1974 and 959 of 1973; Civil Appeal No. 318 of 1974)

facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 34 of 1974 and 959 of 1973 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 34 of 1974 and 959 of 1973. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India and Civil Appeal No. 318 of 1974.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 318 of 1974 arises from judgment and order dated 15th September 1973 of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 38 of 1973.

anchor.surface_text: and Civil Appeal No. 318 of 1974. From the judgment and order dated the 15th September 1973 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 38 of 1973. C. Singhania, C. N. Murthy,  In W.P. No. 34/74 , Madan Bhatia and Shiv Khorana,  In W.P. No. 959/73  and M. K. Garg, for the petitioners  In W.P. No. 34/74 959/73 .

facts.text: Petitioners in Writ Petitions engaged in business of purchase and export of Cinchona products between 1966 and 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAY, C.J.-The two Writ Petitions and the Civil Appeal raise the question as to whether a person who is put on the black list by the State Government is entitled to a notice to be heard before the name is put on the black list. Sale of Cinchona is held by the State Government at meetings of the Sales Committee. Sealed quotations are invited for intending buyers. The State maintains a list of buyers or bidders. The State has the right to reject a bid at an auction. The petitioners in the Writ Petitions were engaged in the business of purchase and export of Cinchona products between the years 1966 and 1971.

facts.text: Petitioners submitted tenders for purchase of Cinchona which were accepted and entered into contracts with State Government during 1966-1971 for large sums.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners in the Writ Petitions were engaged in the business of purchase and export of Cinchona products between the years 1966 and 1971. They submitted tender for purchase of Cinchona. Their tender was accepted. They entered into contracts with the State Government during those years for purchase of Cinchona for large sums of money.

facts.text: Petitioners submitted tender on 15th February 1973 and again on 4 December 1973.

anchor.surface_text: They submitted tender for purchase of Cinchona. Their tender was accepted. They entered into contracts with the State Government during those years for purchase of Cinchona for large sums of money. The petitioners submitted tender once on 15th February, 1973 and again on 4 December, 1973.

facts.text: Since December 1970, all offers of petitioners were rejected though in most cases their offer was the highest.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners submitted tender once on 15th February, 1973 and again on 4 December, 1973. The petitioners allege that since the month of December, 1970 all offers of the petitioners were rejected though in most cases their offer was the highest.

facts.text: Respondent State alleges petitioners guilty of misdeclaration of goods in export transactions.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners contend that there is discrimination and lack of fair play at the sale. The petitioners submit that they are entitled to receive the same treatment and to be given the same chance as anybody else for the purchase of Cinchona. The petitioners are interested in the purchase of Cinchona in course of their trade and business. The respondent State alleges that the petitioners were guilty of misdeclaration of goods in their export transactions.

facts.text: Sales Committee learnt from secret letter from Collector of Customs, Calcutta that petitioners' firm involved in malpractices, case under investigation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent State alleges that the petitioners were guilty of misdeclaration of goods in their export transactions. The Sales Committee of the State learnt from a secret letter from the Collector of Customs, Calcutta that the firm of the petitioners was involved in malpractices, and their case was under investigation.

facts.text: Sales Committee at meeting on 21 January 1971 resolved not to deal with petitioners' firm till cleared of charges of malpractices.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Committee of the State learnt from a secret letter from the Collector of Customs, Calcutta that the firm of the petitioners was involved in malpractices, and their case was under investigation. The Sales Committee at a meeting on 21 January, 1971 resolved not to deal with the firm of the petitioners till the firm was cleared of charges of malpractices.

facts.text: Tenders of petitioners not accepted because of the resolution of 21 January 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Committee at a meeting on 21 January, 1971 resolved not to deal with the firm of the petitioners till the firm was cleared of charges of malpractices. It is because of this resolution that the tender of the petitioners was not accepted.

facts.text: Petitioners came to know of the resolution at Sales Committee meeting on 4 December 1973.

anchor.surface_text: It is because of this resolution that the tender of the petitioners was not accepted. The petitioners according to the respondent came to know this resolution at the meeting of the Sales Committee on 4 December, 1973.

facts.text: State could not produce the original resolution in this Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners according to the respondent came to know this resolution at the meeting of the Sales Committee on 4 December, 1973. The State could not however produce the original resolution in this Court.

facts.text: Petitioners challenged charges and cases under Foreign Exchange Regulations Act in Calcutta High Court Writ Petition No. 959 of 1973, which is pending.

anchor.surface_text: The State could not however produce the original resolution in this Court. It may be mentioned here that the petitioners have challenged the charges and cases under the Foreign Exchange Regulations Act in the High Court at Calcutta in Writ Petition No. 959 of 1973 which is pending.

facts.text: Respondent in Civil Appeal No. 318 of 1974 was on approved list of Director General, Supplies and Disposals since 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in Civil Appeal No. 318 of 1974 was on the, approved list of the Director General, Supplies and Disposals since the year 1942.

facts.text: Last renewal of registration of respondent was on 5 June 1963 for three years.

anchor.surface_text: The last renewal of registration of the respondent was on 5 June, 1963 for three years.

facts.text: Certain reports received against respondent regarding shortage of timber.

anchor.surface_text: Certain reports were received against the respondent regarding shortage of timber.

facts.text: Special Police Establishment took charge of account books of respondent in August 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Police Establishment took charge of account books of the respondent in the month of August, 1964.

facts.text: Departmental enquiry made against store-keeper and store-holder in Bombay Telephone Workshop; suspended in December 1964.

anchor.surface_text: A Departmental enquiry was made against the store-keeper and the Store-holder in the Bombay Telephone Workshop. Those two employees were suspended in the month of December, 1964.

facts.text: On 4 December 1965, department put name of respondent on black list.

anchor.surface_text: On 4 December, 1965 the department put the name of the respondent on the black list.

facts.text: Suspended employees dismissed on 1 June 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The employees of the Government who had been suspended in the year 1964 were dismissed on 1 June, 1967.

facts.text: In January 1968, respondent applied to court for return of account books taken by Special Police Establishment.

anchor.surface_text: In the month of January, 1968 the respondent applied to the Court for return of the account books which had been taken by the Special Police Establishment.

facts.text: In March 1968, account books ordered to be returned.

anchor.surface_text: In the month of March, 1968 the account books were ordered to be returned.

facts.text: Respondent filed Writ Petition in Bombay High Court on 20 January 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed Writ Petition in the High Court at Bombay on 20 January, 1969.

facts.text: On 12 January 1973, Bombay High Court allowed respondent's writ petition setting aside blacklisting order.

anchor.surface_text: On 12 January, 1973 the High Court allowed the writ petition of the respondent setting aside the order whereby the respondent was blacklisted.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed State's appeal against the writ petition allowance.

anchor.surface_text: The State filed an appeal. The High Court of Bombay dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: High Court accepted employees' prayer setting aside their dismissal by order dated 3 August 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The employees who had been dismissed by the State also applied to the High Court for setting aside their dismissal. The High Court accepted the prayer of the employees by an order dated 3 August, 1972.

facts.text: Petitioners challenged the charges in High Court at Calcutta in Writ Petition No. 959 of 1973 which is pending.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned here that the petitioners have challenged the charges and cases under the Foreign Exchange Regulations Act in the High Court at Calcutta in Writ Petition No. 959 of 1973 which is pending.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that authorities will give opportunity to petitioners to represent before blacklisting.

anchor.surface_text: Fundamentals of fair play require that the person concerned should be given an opportunity to represent his case before he is put on the blacklist. With regard to the case of the petitioners, it is made clear that the authorities will give an opportunity to the petitioners to represent their case, and the authorities will hear the petitioners as to whether their name should be put on the blacklist or not.

facts.text: Writ Petitions succeed; Civil Appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, the petitioners succeed. The appeal is dismissed. The parties will pay and bear their own costs.

facts.text: State maintains list of buyers or bidders for Cinchona sales and has right to reject bids.

anchor.surface_text: Sale of Cinchona is held by the State Government at meetings of the Sales Committee. Sealed quotations are invited for intending buyers. The State maintains a list of buyers or bidders. The State has the right to reject a bid at an auction.

The petitioners submit that they are entitled to receive the same treatment and to be given the same chance as anybody else for the purchase of Cinchona. The petitioners are interested in the purchase of Cinchona in course of their trade and business.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are interested in the purchase of Cinchona in course of their trade and business. The respondent State alleges that the petitioners were guilty of misdeclaration of goods in their export transactions.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent State alleges that the petitioners were guilty of misdeclaration of goods in their export transactions. The Sales Committee of the State learnt from a secret letter from the Collector of Customs, Calcutta that the firm of the petitioners was involved in malpractices, and their case was under investigation. The Sales Committee at a meeting on 21 January, 1971 resolved not to deal with the firm of the petitioners till the firm was cleared of charges of malpractices.

arguments.claim: Petitioner not entitled to mandamus as sales contractual; no right to tender acceptance; not discriminatory, await FERA adjudication first

anchor.surface_text: In Writ Petitions counsel for the State submitted that the petitioner was not entitled to any order of mandamus inasmuch as the sales were contractual. It was said that the petitioner was not entitled as of right to acceptance of tender. It was also said that the attitude of the State was not discriminatory against the petitioner but that the State wanted that the pending proceedings against the petitioner for alleged violation of Foreign Exchange Regulation Act should be adjudicated first and thereafter the State would deal with the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Solicitor General on behalf of the appellant in Civil Appeal No. 318 of 1974 made these submissions. The Government could choose any person for entering into a contract. Further, the State could insist on dealing with persons in whom the State had trust for integrity.

arguments.court_reasoning: State can choose but cannot discriminate arbitrarily; must observe equality

arguments.claim: Rights under Articles 14, 19 and 21 do not extend to compelling Government to enter contract

anchor.surface_text: Rights under Articles 14, 19 and 21 do not extend to the compelling of any third party including the Government to negotiate or enter into a contract.

arguments.court_reasoning: No right to compel contract but right to equality of opportunity in bidding

arguments.claim: Duty to act fairly not always duty to hear; only where vested rights

anchor.surface_text: The duty to act fairly may include in many cases duty to act judicially and those would be cases where there is existing vested rights. The duty to act fairly would not always mean a duty to hear the party affected.

arguments.court_reasoning: Blacklisting affects legitimate expectation and privilege, requires hearing as per natural justice

arguments.claim: Natural justice does not apply to rejecting bid or entering contract

anchor.surface_text: Whereas public blacklisting is not confidential, departmental black- listing will be a confidential matter. If natural justice does not come into play in rejecting a bid, natural justice does not operate at the time of entering into contract.

arguments.court_reasoning: Fundamentals of fair play require opportunity before blacklisting

arguments.claim: State's executive power in trade subject to Part III of Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Under Article 298 of the Constitution the Executive power of the Union and the State shall extend to the carrying on of any trade and to the acquisition, holding and disposal of property and the making of contracts for any purpose. The exercise of such powers and functions in trade by the State is subject to Part III of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Equality of opportunity applies to public contracts; State duty to observe equality

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 speaks of equality before the law and equal, protection of the laws. Equality of opportunity should apply to matters of public contracts. The State has the right to trade. The State has there the duty to observe equality.

arguments.claim: Order of blacklisting deprives person of equality of opportunity in public contract

anchor.surface_text: The order of black- listing, has the effect of depriving a person of equality of opportunity in the matter of public contract. A person who is on the approved list is unable to enter into advantageous relations with the Government because of the order of black- listing.

arguments.claim: Person dealing with Government has legitimate interest or expectation

anchor.surface_text: A person who has been dealing with the Government in the matter of sale and purchase of materials has a legitimate interest or expectation.

arguments.claim: No fundamental right to compel contract but right to equal treatment essential to trade/livelihood

anchor.surface_text: No person has a fundamental right to insist that the Government must enter into a contract with him. A citizen has a right to earn livelihood and to pursue any trade. A citizen has a right to claim equal treatment to enter into a contract which may be proper, necessary and essential to his lawful calling.

arguments.claim: Blacklisting has civil consequences, casts slur, creates barrier

anchor.surface_text: The blacklisting order does not pertain to any particular contract. The blacklisting order involves civil consequences. It casts a slur. It creates a barrier between the persons blacklisted and the Government in the matter of transactions.

arguments.claim: Duty to act fairly includes aspects of natural justice before blacklisting

anchor.surface_text: A duty to act fairly can be interpreted as meaning a duty to observe certain aspects of rules of natural justice. [...] Blacklisting has the effect of preventing a person from the privilege and advantage of entering into lawful relationship with the Government for purposes of gains.

arguments.claim: Fundamentals of fair play require opportunity to represent before putting on blacklist

anchor.surface_text: Fundamentals of fair play require that the person concerned should be given an opportunity to represent his case before he is put on the blacklist.

holdings.text: Fundamentals of fair play require that the person concerned should be given an opportunity to represent his case before he is put on the blacklist.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Blacklisting prevents privilege of entering contracts, creates civil consequences like slur and barrier, affects legitimate expectation from prior dealings; requires objective satisfaction and natural justice audi alteram partem.

holdings.text: With regard to the case of the petitioners, it is made clear that the authorities will give an opportunity to the petitioners to represent their case, and the authorities will hear the petitioners as to whether their name should be put on the blacklist or not.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application to facts of writ petitioners; no prejudice to pending FERA proceedings.

holdings.text: The order of blacklisting has the effect of depriving a person of equality of opportunity in the matter of public contract.

anchor.surface_text: The order of black- listing, has the effect of depriving a person of equality of opportunity in the matter of public contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 14 requires equality before law and equal protection; applies to public contracts where state trades.

holdings.text: The exercise of such powers and functions in trade by the State is subject to Part III of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The exercise of such powers and functions in trade by the State is subject to Part III of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 298 executive power in trade subject to fundamental rights including Art 14.

holdings.text: Equality of opportunity should apply to matters of public contracts. The State has the right to trade. The State has there the duty to observe equality.

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 speaks of equality before the law and equal, protection of the laws. Equality of opportunity should apply to matters of public contracts. The State has the right to trade.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State cannot arbitrarily discriminate in choosing contractors; must afford equal treatment.

holdings.text: A person who has been dealing with the Government in the matter of sale and purchase of materials has a legitimate interest or expectation.

anchor.surface_text: A person who has been dealing with the Government in the matter of sale and purchase of materials has a legitimate interest or expectation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior approved dealings create expectation to continue bidding absent valid reason.

holdings.text: No person has a fundamental right to insist that the Government must enter into a contract with him. A citizen has a right to claim equal treatment to enter into a contract which may be proper, necessary and essential to his lawful calling.

anchor.surface_text: No person has a fundamental right to insist that the Government must enter into a contract with him. A citizen has a right to earn livelihood and to pursue any trade.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No right to compel contract but Art 14 protects equality in opportunity for contracts vital to trade/livelihood.

holdings.text: The blacklisting order involves civil consequences. It casts a slur. It creates a barrier between the persons blacklisted and the Government in the matter of transactions.

anchor.surface_text: The blacklisting order does not pertain to any particular contract. The blacklisting order involves civil consequences. It casts a slur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Civil consequences trigger duty to act fairly including natural justice elements.

holdings.text: For these reasons, the petitioners succeed. The appeal is dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above principles to facts; no hearing given, blacklisting invalid.
